body: Sterilize de-hulled rice seeds \(Oryza sativa L. cv. Dongjin) in 70% \(v/v) ethanol for 5 min, wash once with sterile water, once in 3% \(wt/v) sodium hypochlorite for 20 min, and three times with sterile water. Imbibe sterilized seeds under dark conditions at 4°C for 1 day, then grow seeds on 1% \(wt/v) Phytagel<sup>®</sup> in a 28°C chamber \(16 h light per day). Transplant 1-week-old seedlings into field soil and allow for growth up to the 4-6 leaf stage.

title: **▲Critical step**
body: The quality of leaf sheaths strongly influences the experimental results. Ensure healthy plant growth.

title: **Preparation of tungsten M-17 particles ● TIMING 30 min \(prior to bombardment)**

body: Wash 60 mg of tungsten particles with 1 ml of 95% \(v/v) ethanol by vortexing for 5 min and incubating at room temperature for 15 min. Collect the particles with a quick spin for 10 sec at 14,000×g and remove supernatant by pipetting. Wash the particulate pellet three times with 1 ml of nuclease-free water by vortexing followed by a quick spin. Add 1 ml of nuclease-free water and aliquot 100 μl volumes into microfuge tubes.

title: **■ PAUSE POINT**
body: Prepared particles can be stored at -20°C for up to 6 months.

title: **Preparation of bombardment disks ● TIMING 3 h \(prior to bombardment)**

body: Immerse macrocarrier holder, rupture disks, macrocarrier disk, and stopping screens in 100% ethanol for 2 h to prevent contamination. Air-dry on a clean bench for 30 min and place the macrocarrier disk into the macrocarrier holder using tweezers.

title: **Preparation of leaf sheaths for bombardment ● TIMING 3 h**

body: Cut the leaf sheaths and stems from 4-6-leaf stage rice plants \(Fig. 1a). Cut the leaf sheath near the flag leaf auricle to a length of 2-3 cm, using a razor blade on a slide \(Fig. 1b). Softly catch the side of the sheath and slice the sheath in parallel with the sheath section blade \(Fig. 1c). The distance between the two blades should be 0.3-0.5 mm \(Fig. 1d). Select leaf sheaths with smooth surfaces and trim \(Fig. 1e). Hold the sheath by its edges with tweezers and slowly place it on to a half-strength MS plate.

title: **▲Critical step**
body: The quality of the leaf sheaths is essential for optimal sheath sectioning. Leaf sheaths with limited lignification and sufficient thickness are best suited for this technique \(Fig. 1b). The slicing process will strongly influence the subsequent bombardment and microscopic detection. Smooth sections give the best results.
Gently place 6-8 sliced sheaths onto the medium of a half-strength MS plate and incubate at 28°C for 1-2 h in the dark.
Vortex the microcarriers for 10 min to disrupt agglomeration. Transfer 20 μl of the suspended microcarriers into a new microfuge tube.
Add to the 20 μl of tungsten microcarriers, in this order: 2 μg of plasmid DNA \(1 μg/μl), 20 μl of 2.5 M CaCl<sub>2</sub>, and 8 μl of 0.1 M spermidine. Vortex for 2 min.
Centrifuge the samples at 14,000×g for 10 sec and discard the supernatant.

Without suspending the pellet, gently wash the pellet with 250 μl and 100 μl of 95% ethanol in series. Suspend the pellet in 20 μl 95% ethanol, transfer to the center of the macrocarrier, and air dry.
Set up the bombardment equipment as per the manufacturer’s instructions and bombard the sheaths at 1,100 psi.
Incubate the bombarded sheaths at 28°C for 1-2 days under darkness until expression of the delivered transgene is confirmed.

title: **Fluorescent microscopic identification of the expressed gene ● TIMING 1-2 h**

body: Mount a sheath in a drop of sterile, distilled water on a glass slide and cover with a cover glass. For mCherry signals, images can be generated using a laser scanning microscope with an excitation wavelength of 543 nm and the signal \(emitted fluorescence) can be measured at 587-625 nm.
